Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: We have multiple distinct application sessions. We see these apps: Microsoft Word, Google Chrome, Adobe Acrobat, Microsoft Excel. The tasks can be considered as separate cases possibly? But instructions indicate that A case might represent a logical unit of user work such as editing a specific document or handling a particular email or reviewing a certain PDF. We have multiple sequences: 1) Theres an event sequence for Microsoft Word with Document1.docx and then later switching to different things. Lets try to analyze: Timestamp events: - 2024-12-11T08:59:50.000Z, FOCUS, App=Microsoft Word, Window=Quarterly_Report.docx - 2024-12-11T09:00:00.000Z, FOCUS, App=Microsoft Word, Window=Document1.docx   * so user is switching to Document1.docx from Quarterly_Report.docx maybe? But then after that sequence on Document1: TYPING, SAVE etc. - 2024-12-11T09:00:30.000Z, TYPING, App=Microsoft Word, Window=Document1.docx, Keys=Draft intro paragraph - 2024-12-11T09:01:00.000Z, TYPING, App=Microsoft Word, Window=Document1.docx, Keys=Additional details here - 2024-12-11T09:01:15.000Z, SAVE, App=Microsoft Word, Window=Document1.docx So this sequence is likely a process case Edit Document1 maybe. Then next event: - 2024-12-11T09:01:45.000Z, SWITCH, FromApp=Microsoft Word, FromWindow=Document1.docx, ToApp=Google Chrome, ToWindow=Email - Inbox So user switches from editing document to Google Chromes email inbox. That signals a new case Check Email maybe. Then sequence on Chrome: - 2024-12-11T09:02:00.000Z, CLICK, App=Google Chrome, Window=Email - Inbox, Action=Open Email about Annual Meeting - 2024-12-11T09:02:30.000Z, SCROLL, App=Google Chrome, Window=Email - Inbox, Direction=Down - 2024-12-11T09:02:45.000Z, CLICK, App=Google Chrome, Window=Email - Inbox, Action=Reply to Email - 2024-12-11T09:03:00.000Z, TYPING, App=Google Chrome, Window=Email - Inbox, Keys=Meeting details confirmed - 2024-12-11T09:03:20.000Z, CLICK, App=Google Chrome, Window=Email - Inbox, Action=Send Email So thats a Compose and Send Reply Email process. Then: - 2024-12-11T09:04:00.000Z, SWITCH, FromApp=Google Chrome,FromWindow=Email - Inbox, ToApp=Adobe Acrobat,ToWindow=Report_Draft.pdf   * so the user switches to Adobe Acrobat for reviewing PDF document. - Then sequence in Acrobat:   - 2024-12-11T09:04:30.000Z, SCROLL, App=Adobe Acrobat, Window=Report_Draft.pdf, Direction=Down   - 2024-12-11T09:04:45.000Z, HIGHLIGHT, App=Adobe Acrobat, Window=Report_Draft.pdf, Text=Key Findings So thats a Review PDF Document case. Then: - 2024-12-11T09:05:00.000Z, FOCUS, App=Microsoft Excel, Window=Budget_2024.xlsx   * This is a new session for updating the budget. - Then sequence in Excel:   - TYPING events on Excel with keys Update Q1 figures and Insert new row for Q2, then SAVE event. That yields a Edit Budget Excel Document case. - Then:   - 2024-12-11T09:06:00.000Z, SWITCH, FromApp=Microsoft Excel, FromWindow=Budget_2024.xlsx, ToApp=Microsoft Word,ToWindow=Document1.docx     * user goes back to Microsoft Words Document1.docx. - Then sequence in Word:   - TYPING event Inserting reference to budget   - SAVE event for Document1.docx - Then CLOSE event on Document1.docx. Then next: - 2024-12-11T09:07:15.000Z, FOCUS, App=Microsoft Word, Window=Quarterly_Report.docx   * So the user goes back to Quarterly Report. - Then sequence in Word for quarterly report:   - TYPING event Executive Summary draft   - SAVE event.   - CLOSE event.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - IND
Text: So now how to group into cases: They are logically separate tasks. We can have multiple cases per session if we assume each distinct process instance is a case. But instructions mention that a case represents a logical unit of user work such as editing a specific document, handling an email etc. So Id assign a unique Case ID for each process group. Alternatively, we might also consider that the same Document1.docx was edited twice: first edit in session starting at T09:00 and then later after Excel switch back to Word Document1 doc maybe representing a reference update? But instructions say a case can represent a logical unit of user work so each distinct process instance should be a separate case. Possibly we want to group events that belong together based on their activity context.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Group 1: Editing Document1.docx as part of an initial document creation process: - Timestamps from T09:00:00 FOCUS on Document1.docx, then typing events (T09:00:30 and T09:01:00) until SAVE at T09:01:15. Thus one process instance Edit Document1 case. Lets assign Case ID: DOC1_Edit. Group 2: Email handling: - Timestamps from T09:01:45 switching to Chrome (Email inbox), then sequence of clicking, scrolling, replying, typing and sending email. This is clearly an email processing case. So assign EMAIL_Response maybe. Group 3: PDF review: - After that, at T09:04:00 switching to Adobe Acrobats Report_Draft.pdf. Sequence: SCROLL, HIGHLIGHT. So process instance Review_Report. Case ID PDF_Review. Group 4: Excel budget update: - Timestamps from T09:05:00 FOCUS on Microsoft Excel (Budget_2024.xlsx), then TYPING events and SAVE event. Process instance Update_Budget case. Group 5: Returning to Document1.docx for reference update: - At T09:06:00, switching back to Word with Document1.docx. Then TYPING event at T09:06:15 (Inserting reference to budget), then SAVE event, and CLOSE. So process instance Update_Document1_Reference maybe. Group 6: Quarterly report editing: - At T09:07:15 FOCUS on Microsoft Word with Quarterly_Report.docx. Then TYPING event at T09:07:45 (Executive Summary draft) then SAVE and CLOSE. Process instance Edit_Quarterly_Report.  But note the earlier event T08:59:50 FOCUS on Quarterly_Report.docx might be part of a previous session? Possibly the first focus event is not used because its before switching to Document1. Actually, timeline: At 08:59:50, user focuses on Microsoft Word with Quarterly_Report.docx. Then at 09:00:00, user switches to Document1.docx from MS Word (so maybe they had two documents open concurrently). Then later at 09:07:15, user goes back to Quarterly_Report.docx and edits it. So its a separate process instance.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - IND
Text: We need to decide whether each distinct file editing is a case or if a document can have multiple sessions. The instructions say A case can represent a logical unit of user work, such as editing a specific document. But we see that Document1.docx appears twice with different edits (initial draft and later update reference). They might be considered separate process cases. Alternatively, they could be combined into one case representing the entire editing session for that document. However, note: The event log lines are separated by SWITCH events indicating transitions between tasks. In particular: Sequence of Document1.docx from 09:00 to 09:01:15 (edit initial draft) then a switch to email. Then later at 09:06:00 switching back to Document1.docx and doing a reference insertion update, then close it. So question: Should we treat the two edits on Document1 as separate cases or combine them into one? The instructions are ambiguous. But since case is defined as a logical unit of work. In this scenario, editing Document1.docx might be considered the same process if they belong to the same overall work item (i.e., writing Document1). However, the switching event in between indicates an interruption. Often, in process mining, cases are persistent over time. So perhaps its better to combine events that are about the same document into one case instance because they share a common case identifier Document1.docx but then we have two separate edits on Document1?

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Let me check: The initial sequence for Document1.docx starts at 09:00:00 and ends with SAVE at 09:01:15. Then later, at 09:06:00, the user switches back to Document1 doc to insert a reference to budget. If we consider them as separate cases, then we have two different cases for Document1. But if they are logically part of same document editing session, maybe they belong in one case? However, note that theres an interruption by email and PDF review, Excel budget update. The user might be doing several tasks concurrently over a single workday. So it is common to have separate process instances (cases) for each task. But I think the instructions say: A case can represent a logical unit of user work so likely its better to treat them as separate cases if they are different tasks in that day? But Document1.docx might be seen as one case because it is an instance of editing that document. However, the sequence is interrupted by other processes and then returned to, but still on the same document, it might be considered a continuation of the same case. Lets see: The system log is not clearly partitioned into sessions with a clear session ID except for file names. But we can assign Case IDs based on the document name if we assume that editing a specific file is one process instance. However, there are two separate sequences for Document1.docx events. In many process mining scenarios, cases represent business processes (like handling an order, a loan application, etc.). Here each case could be considered as a separate task (email response, budget update, report review, and document editing). But Document1 appears twice. If we consider the same file being worked on in separate sessions as one continuous process instance, then it would have multiple events with the same Case ID. That might be acceptable if they share common data element. But the instruction says each event in the final log should correspond to a meaningful activity in a process instance (case). And also: Identify how to group related events into coherent cases. A case can represent a logical unit of user work, such as editing a specific document. So we have several distinct documents being edited. We see Document1 doc is a candidate for one case if its editing tasks are all part of the same process instance. But note that theres an interruption between the two editing sessions for Document1. The first session ends with a SAVE event at 09:01:15, then user switches to another app and returns later to Document1.docx. There is a gap (switching events in-between). It might be appropriate to treat it as one case if we assume that the same document editing process is continuous even if interrupted by other tasks. I can assign Case ID Document1 for all events related to Document1.docx, because both sessions refer to that file. But then what about Quarterly_Report.docx? There are two events: T08:59:50 FOCUS and T09:07:15 FOCUS. They might represent the same process instance if the user left it open earlier and then returned later. However, typically the FOCUS event at T08:59:50 is a window focus event, but does not necessarily indicate editing if no subsequent events occur for that file? Actually we see that later T09:07:15 FOCUS on Quarterly_Report.docx, then typing event and save, so maybe its intended to be the same case. But what about the first focus event at T08:59:50 on Quarterly_Report.docx which is not followed by any editing events until later? It might just be opening the file? Possibly it could be considered as part of Prepare Quarterly Report process instance, but then the actual editing happens later at 09:07:15. I think we want to group them together if they refer to the same document file and theres no other activity in between. But note that T08:59:50 might not really count because it is before switching to Document1 doc. So maybe its a separate case? Alternatively, if the user had both documents open simultaneously, then focusing on one at T08:59:50 is just a window focus event and then later editing the same file may be part of same session. However, there is no typing or save events for Quarterly_Report until 09:07:15, so the initial FOCUS might not be considered as process activity if its not followed by an action. I have to decide on case grouping: - Lets group based on window/document names and also consider switching events. So we can assign: Case Document1 for all events related to Document1.docx. The first session: 09:00:00 - 09:01:15 and then the second session: 09:06:00 - 09:07:00 (SAVE and CLOSE) become one case if we assume continuous work on that document. - Case Email for events related to email inbox handling. - Case PDF for events with Adobe Acrobat on Report_Draft.pdf. - Case Budget for events in Excel Budget_2024.xlsx - Case Quarterly_Report for editing Quarterly_Report.docx. The only editing event is at 09:07:15 onward. What about the initial FOCUS event at T08:59:50 for Quarterly_Report.docx? It is associated with file Quarterly_Report.docx. So assign that to same case Quarterly_Report.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: I want to decide naming of activities in process mining: - For FOCUS events, I might use Open [Application/Window] since its the action that begins editing. - For TYPING events, maybe Edit Content but we can also name them by their content if possible. But instructions say standardize to higher-level process steps. But we want consistent naming for each type of event: FOCUS becomes Start Activity, TYPING becomes Edit Document maybe with description? Or I might simply use the documents purpose as the activity name. For example, when editing Document1.docx, use Draft Introduction if keys indicate that? But instructions say we want standardized activities rather than raw action verbs. Maybe best approach: Group events by case and then assign a single high-level activity label for each case based on the file type or purpose: - For Document1 doc: The first editing session: maybe call it Edit Document1 (or Write Document1 Draft). - For Email inbox: Compose Email Response. - For Adobe Acrobat PDF: Review Report Draft. - For Excel Budget update: Update Budget Figures. - For Quarterly_Report doc: Edit Quarterly Report. But then how do we incorporate multiple steps within a case? Perhaps each event gets an activity name that is derived from the raw action verb but standardized. But instructions say include at least Case ID, Activity Name, Timestamp. I can assign Activity names as follows: For FOCUS events: - For Document1.docx: Edit Document or Draft Introduction. But then subsequent TYPING events could be considered as part of that same process. However, if we want to capture multiple activities in one case instance, then each event gets a separate row with an activity name representing what was done.
